mechanics.condition: Natural terrain within a 150-foot cube in range
mechanics.outcome: Terrain appears, sounds, and smells like a different natural terrain type (e.g., field to swamp, pond to meadow)

mechanics.condition: Target within the area is a manufactured structure, equipment, or creature
mechanics.outcome: Target's appearance is NOT changed by the illusion

mechanics.trigger: Creature physically interacts with the illusion
mechanics.outcome: Tactile characteristics of the terrain are unchanged, making it likely for the creature to perceive the illusion

mechanics.condition: Tactile difference is NOT obvious by touch
mechanics.outcome: Creature can attempt an Intelligence (Investigation) check against the spell save DC to disbelieve the illusion

mechanics.condition: Creature discerns the illusion for what it is
mechanics.outcome: Creature sees the illusion as a vague image superimposed on the actual terrain

description_text: You make natural terrain in a 150-foot cube in range look, sound, and smell like some other sort of natural terrain. Thus, open fields or a road can be made to resemble a swamp, hill, crevasse, or some other difficult or impassable terrain. A pond can be made to seem like a grassy meadow, a precipice like a gentle slope, or a rock-strewn gully like a wide and smooth road. Manufactured structures, equipment, and creatures within the area aren't changed in appearance. The tactile characteristics of the terrain are unchanged, so creatures entering the area are likely to see through the illusion. If the difference isn't obvious by touch, a creature carefully examining the illusion can attempt an Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC to disbelieve it. A creature who discerns the illusion for what it is, sees it as a vague image superimposed on the terrain.
